S. A. ALLOTMENTS
AGAIN RECEIVE
HUGE REDUCTION

JOHN WEEKS CHOSEN
SENIOR CLASS HEAD

of the University, and Theodore
Stern, President of the Student Activities Council.
This group faced two serious
problems in making the decision to
further pare down the already drastically slashed expense allowances of
the undergraduate extra-curricular
bodies. First, there were numerous
debts carried over from the past
year, the funds for the payment of
which are as yet tied up in the restricted Union Trust Company accounts. These bills had to be met
in some manner, although the only
funds available were those allotted
for the carrying on of campus affairs for the current terms. Secondly, there was the problem of
providing sufficient funds for the
operation of the activities for the
current year.

Undergraduates To
Attend Meeting Of
InternationalClub

In an attempt to keep the International Relations Club in existence,
the group has scheduled a revival
meeting to be held at 12:30 p. m.
Wednesday in Gilman 305.
All undergraduates interested in
the work of the society which con- Presides Over Local
I. N. A. Convention
sists of a study of international relations with a particular bearing on
world peace, are invited to attend
the meeting in order to maintain
the work of the club and to prevent
its disbanding.
The group is affiliated with the
Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, and has been receiving
books and other material pertaining
to the subject and the work of the
organization from the Endowment.

TO OPEN DOHME
LECTURES TODAY
Dr. Hugh S. Taylor Speaks
On Problems Involving
Heavy Hydrogen
"Theoretical and Experimental
Research Problems Involving Heavy
Hydrogen" is the title of the first
Dohme lecture to be delivered by
Dr. Hugh Scott Taylor, chairman of
the Chemistry department of
Princeton University, today at 4
p. m. in Remsen 101.
Under the sponsorship of Dr. A.
R. L. Dohme, an alumnus of the
Hopkins, the department of chemistry has had a series of addresses
by prominent scientific men for the
last four years. Men noted in the
field of physical and chemical sciences are brought to the University
to address the chemical students.

Creditors Give Discount

Experiments Outlined

After prolonged discussion, a
plan was decided upon whereby both
ends would be attained. Several
creditors agreed to substantial discounts if payments were made immediately and in cash, and these
were met in full from the funds set
aside for this year. The balance
of those owed by the University
activity groups were paid 60 per
cent on their accounts at the present, the payment of the remaining
40 per cent being deferred until the
exact situation regarding the money
on deposit in the Union Trust becomes known. Pending the outcome of this matter, a sum somewhat in excess of this 40 per cent
indebtedness is being held by the
University treasurer. All small ac(Continued on Page 4, Col. 4)

In his lecture, Dr. Taylor will review the theoretical problems arising from the demonstration of the
separation of hydrogen isotopes by
electrolysis. Details will be given
of the plant used at Princeton for
the separation and of its efficiency.
Experiments involving the kinetics and equilibria of hydrogen isotopes including adsorption, diffusion
and chemical reactions, will be outlined and the results discussed.

D. Of C. Pay Visit
To Hopkins Library
Members of the Daughters of the
Confederacy were guests of the
University yesterday. The group
made an inspection tour of the library under the direction of Dr.
John C. French.

I. N. A. CONVENES ON CAMPUS
FOR ANNUAL FALL CONCLAVE
WITH 30 PAPERS REPRESENTED

All delegates to the Interfraternity Board were instructed, at the
Board meeting Monday, to ask the
members of their respective fraternities whether the Board should be
represented on the Student Activities Council. The delegates will
receive the decision of the fraternities this Wednesday night and further action will be taken at the meeting next Monday, it was announced.
The Board decided to give three
cups as prizes for the interfraternity bowling league. A large cup
will be presented to the winning fraternity and a smaller cup given to

The students have certainly given their willing
cooperation to the administration, but as individuals
and not as a Council. The Council has not even met
since all the discussion about activities has been in
progress. They themselves have more confidence in
their individual influence than in that of the Council. It is almost impossible for them, in this state of
mnd, to commit themselves to a sufficiently unified
action to have any weight with the students. In fact,
take any ten men who are not in any way connected
with activities, but who are affected because of the
fee they pay, and at least five of them cannot tell you
the difference between the Student Council and the
Student Activities Council, or the significance of the
latter.
In the light of the foregoing considerations we
are at a loss to see any justification for the Council.
At the critical moment in the budget situation last
year 0. D. K. had to step in and investigate the situation, logically being the function of the Council.
However, if the Dean is willing to join us in crying
quits we'll throw the whole matter overboard. Even
if we had convinced the rest of the fellows on the
campus that the Council is an encumbrance they
wouldn't have the energy to wash it out.
What's the use, Dean Berry, what's the use.

Breaking a tradition that has existed for twenty-odd years, the
Johns Hopkins football team will
tneet the University of Maryland
eleven at Homewood, tomorrow, instead of at the Baltimore Stadium
On Thanksgiving Day.
After going through comparatively mediocre schedules, both
teams are priming for an inspired
struggle. As usual the rivalry that
exists between the Jays and the
Terps should be sufficient to make
the game exceedingly interesting
and closely fought.

HUGE REDUCTION

JOHN WEEKS CHOSEN
SENIOR CLASS HEAD

of the University, and Theodore
Stern, President of the Student Activities Council.
This group faced two serious
problems in making the decision to
further pare down the already drastically slashed expense allowances of
the undergraduate extra-curricular
bodies. First, there were numerous
debts carried over from the past
year, the funds for the payment of
which are as yet tied up in the restricted Union Trust Company accounts. These bills had to be met
in some manner, although the only
funds available were those allotted
for the carrying on of campus affairs for the current terms. Secondly, there was the problem of
providing sufficient funds for the
operation of the activities for the
current year.

Undergraduates To
Attend Meeting Of
InternationalClub

In an attempt to keep the International Relations Club in existence,
the group has scheduled a revival
meeting to be held at 12:30 p. m.
Wednesday in Gilman 305.
All undergraduates interested in
the work of the society which con- Presides Over Local
I. N. A. Convention
sists of a study of international relations with a particular bearing on
world peace, are invited to attend
the meeting in order to maintain
the work of the club and to prevent
its disbanding.
The group is affiliated with the
Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, and has been receiving
books and other material pertaining
to the subject and the work of the
organization from the Endowment.

TO OPEN DOHME
LECTURES TODAY
Dr. Hugh S. Taylor Speaks
On Problems Involving
Heavy Hydrogen
"Theoretical and Experimental
Research Problems Involving Heavy
Hydrogen" is the title of the first
Dohme lecture to be delivered by
Dr. Hugh Scott Taylor, chairman of
the Chemistry department of
Princeton University, today at 4
p. m. in Remsen 101.
Under the sponsorship of Dr. A.
R. L. Dohme, an alumnus of the
Hopkins, the department of chemistry has had a series of addresses
by prominent scientific men for the
last four years. Men noted in the
field of physical and chemical sciences are brought to the University
to address the chemical students.

Creditors Give Discount

Experiments Outlined

After prolonged discussion, a
plan was decided upon whereby both
ends would be attained. Several
creditors agreed to substantial discounts if payments were made immediately and in cash, and these
were met in full from the funds set
aside for this year. The balance
of those owed by the University
activity groups were paid 60 per
cent on their accounts at the present, the payment of the remaining
40 per cent being deferred until the
exact situation regarding the money
on deposit in the Union Trust becomes known. Pending the outcome of this matter, a sum somewhat in excess of this 40 per cent
indebtedness is being held by the
University treasurer. All small ac(Continued on Page 4, Col. 4)

In his lecture, Dr. Taylor will review the theoretical problems arising from the demonstration of the
separation of hydrogen isotopes by
electrolysis. Details will be given
of the plant used at Princeton for
the separation and of its efficiency.
Experiments involving the kinetics and equilibria of hydrogen isotopes including adsorption, diffusion
and chemical reactions, will be outlined and the results discussed.

The students have certainly given their willing
cooperation to the administration, but as individuals
and not as a Council. The Council has not even met
since all the discussion about activities has been in
progress. They themselves have more confidence in
their individual influence than in that of the Council. It is almost impossible for them, in this state of
mnd, to commit themselves to a sufficiently unified
action to have any weight with the students. In fact,
take any ten men who are not in any way connected
with activities, but who are affected because of the
fee they pay, and at least five of them cannot tell you
the difference between the Student Council and the
Student Activities Council, or the significance of the
latter.
In the light of the foregoing considerations we
are at a loss to see any justification for the Council.
At the critical moment in the budget situation last
year 0. D. K. had to step in and investigate the situation, logically being the function of the Council.
However, if the Dean is willing to join us in crying
quits we'll throw the whole matter overboard. Even
if we had convinced the rest of the fellows on the
campus that the Council is an encumbrance they
wouldn't have the energy to wash it out.
What's the use, Dean Berry, what's the use.

GAME SCHEDULED
TO START AT 2 P. M.

Breaking a tradition that has existed for twenty-odd years, the
Johns Hopkins football team will
tneet the University of Maryland
eleven at Homewood, tomorrow, instead of at the Baltimore Stadium
On Thanksgiving Day.
After going through comparatively mediocre schedules, both
teams are priming for an inspired
struggle. As usual the rivalry that
exists between the Jays and the
Terps should be sufficient to make
the game exceedingly interesting
and closely fought.
